title: provide specialized message if we can say what the fix is

We can't imagine everything the user could do wrong, but when we can anticipate problems, and give feedback without adding too much cruft to our code, seems worth considering.

Maybe the error message should just be replaced instead of being appended?

title: grouping columns example
body:
- Fix #1488

This runs locally with faker and pandas installed, but I think we'd prefer not to add those as dev dependencies?

I'm also just not sure how persuasive this example is: It feels like we're doing a lot of work to just pull one example from a very small set.

Proposal: The fake dataset should have a lot of columns, and the column data should vary systematically, so we can see that it's picking a good set of columns. My hope is that if we gave it
- 10 columns of constant values
- 10 columns of small random integers 0-9
- and 10 columns of random floats

it would pick the small random integer columns for grouping. Is that the behavior we'd expect, and would it make a good example?

title: Remove `Any` from generated python
body:
- Fix #1505

If this causes any problems, we should just drop it and close the issue, but I think this will make the docs a little more readable.
- The `Any` annotation doesn't add anything in terms of type checking.
- In some cases, it makes the documentation a little confusing, when the semantics of the function make it clear that `Any` is not really the intention.

`Any` tuples may still be in the generated code, but it's not possible to specify a tuple only by length.

title: R examples in docs via stand-alone files
body:
- fixes #1490

Had some problems at first: notes below.

<details>

The machinery essentially works, but the example itself fails, at least as it is being run in my environment.

https://rstudio.github.io/r-manuals/r-exts/Writing-R-documentation-files.html explains that examples are run by default:
> `\examples{...}`
>
> Examples of how to use the function. Code in this section is set in typewriter font without reformatting and is run by example() unless marked otherwise (see below).

And what we see in the generated documentation isn't pretty:

`opendp/R/opendp/docs/reference/atom_domain.html`:
> Examples
> ```
> atom_domain(.T = "i32")
> #> Error in .Call("domains__atom_domain", bounds, nullable, .T, rt_parse(.T.bounds),     log, PACKAGE = "opendp"): "domains__atom_domain" not available for .Call() for package "opendp"
> ```

https://r-pkgs.org/man.html#sec-man-examples has a lot of information on writing examples, and I haven't read it yet.

Filing as draft.
- The example needs to work.
- If it doesn't, there should be a CI failure, and I'm not sure that there is one right now.

</details>

title: More R linting (rebased)
body:
- Rebase of #1360

After rebasing that branch, though it would be safest to start a new branch and new PR, in case something went wrong. Notes from original PR below.

> Apply fixes and ignores so that that fewer linting rules need to be ignored. All the changes in this set seem reasonable to me. Looking ahead, I'm not sure how much farther to push linting:
> 
>     # If "linters_with_defaults" is used then only these problems are reported:
>     indentation_linter = NULL, # Indentation should be ... spaces but is ... spaces.
> 
> Requires changes to code gen:
> - #1368 is a first step,
> 
> and then need to regen the r code, and make hand edits in the other files.
> 
>     line_length_linter = NULL, # Lines should not be more than 80 characters.
> 
> Do we care about long lines?
> 
>     object_length_linter = NULL, # Variable and function names should not be longer than 30 characters.
>     object_name_linter = NULL, # Variable and function name style should match snake_case or symbols.
> 
> Fixing these could require bigger changes to our conventions.
> 
>     # With "all_linters", these problems are also reported:
>     expect_identical_linter = NULL, # Use expect_identical(x, y) by default; resort to expect_equal() only when needed, e.g. when setting ignore_attr= or tolerance=.
>     expect_s3_class_linter = NULL, # expect_s3_class(x, k) is better than expect_equal(class(x), k). Note also expect_s4_class() available for testing S4 objects.
> 
> Seem ok, but the second should probably be tackled first, since it's a smaller set.
> 
>     extraction_operator_linter = NULL, # Use `[[` instead of `$` to extract an element.
> 
> Not sure the suggested change is always the best idiom
> 
>     implicit_integer_linter = NULL, # Integers should not be implicit. Use the form 1L for integers or 1.0 for doubles.
> 
> Seems excessive to me?
> 
>     routine_registration_linter = NULL, # Register your native code routines with useDynLib and R_registerRoutines().
> 
> Feeling out of my depth on this one, and what the implications might be.
> 
>     todo_comment_linter = NULL, # TODO comments should be removed.
> 
> I think TODOs can have a place, in conjunction with issues to track and surface issues.
> 
>     undesirable_function_linter = NULL, # Function "library" is undesirable. As an alternative, use roxygen2's @importFrom statement in packages and `::` in scripts, instead of modifying the global search path.
>     undesirable_operator_linter = NULL, # Operator `<<-` is undesirable. It assigns outside the current environment in a way that can be hard to reason about. Prefer fully-encapsulated functions wherever possible, or, if necessary, assign to a specific environment with assign(). Recall that you can create an environment at the desired scope with new.env().
> 
> Global side effects aren't good... but it's also possible that we're relying on these side effects now, so we'd want to be cautious here. 
> 
>     unused_import_linter = NULL # Package 'testthat' is attached but never used.
> 
> I think this must be doing something useful for us, or it wouldn't have been included?
> 
>

title: Upgrade github actions
body:
- Fix #1372

There are backward incompatible changes to artifacts: Formerly, they were mutable, and you could add files to an artifact in multiple steps. On a quick skim of the code, I don't think we were using that functionality, but I could be wrong. Steps from here:
- Confirm that smoke-test passes
  - and that there are no Node 16 warnings
- Run the build manually, and confirm that it passes. (Wait until #1350 is merged to main, and then merge main to this branch, before trying to run manually.)
  - and that there are no Node 16 warnings
- Do a more thorough inspection to see if there are any workflows the steps above didn't cover, or if there are places where we're using the mutability of artifacts, but the testing wasn't strong enough.

Draft for now.

steps:

Thought about introducing wrapper functions `indent_2` and `indent_4`, but this seems simpler, but no strong feelings.

Implicitly tested by the check for local changes to the generated code after the cargo build.

title: Call mypy and flake8 as subprocesses from pytest
body:
- Fix #1357
- `vendor` is a new directory to ignore
- Simpler CI config
- For developers, just running `pytest` locally will catch more of the simple mistakes

`python-notebooks` might be added... but it is fairly slow, and also has an additional dependency.

Also considered adding the check for local modifications (`git diff --exit-code`) but local modifications are absolutely routine during development, so this would often give false positives if run locally.

title: Minimal cargo test

labels.name: CI
labels.description: Anything related to CI, Github Actions, and the mechanics of the release process

body:
- Towards #1338

We want to make sure Rust OpenDP works with a minimal set of features. A place to start is a test of the current behavior, and it would also be nice to integrate it with the docs. [Example runs in CI.](https://github.com/opendp/opendp/actions/runs/8198565310/job/22422292886#step:3:162)

Down the road we probably want to do something like rewrite the `Cargo.toml` during test so it uses the local source code... but for documentation for external users, we need something that pulls from crates.io, rather than the local checkout.

I'm not sure if there's a more elegant way to organize this than running `cargo init` on the directory: It would be nice to have the rust code sample next to the other code samples, but cargo works well because of conventions and I'm not sure we should fight that.

Some other edits to the RST, and move closing tags to the next line: the snippets were being truncated.

title: Fix nightly
body:
- Fix #1349

envvar usage prevented CI from starting. See https://github.com/opendp/opendp/actions/runs/8135561781/workflow. The problem is really with `release.yml`, not `nightly.yml`. Simplify, by just repeating `inputs.dry_run || inputs.fake`. In some cases, only check `fake`, because not every `dry_run` is also `fake`

- Does the usage of `dry_run` vs `fake` now represent the behavior we want?
- Do we really need to support `fake`? I guess the idea is to speed up the build when we're exercising other parts of this... but I think it has been confusing.
- If we do want to support it, would it be more clear to have a select with three options, rather than than two checkboxes, one of which implies the other?

Need to manually run nightly on this branch and confirm that it works.

milestone.title: 2024-Q2:  Doc Restructuring
milestone.description:
Restructure the documents with an emphasis on a "Getting Started" section for data scientists and developers first learning about DP. This will use examples from the more ergonomic Context API

Deeper conceptual knowledge of DP will be transitioned into other areass including a "Theory" section.

Reference: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1gyVnixpNymYpfhmqYZBEn_2CpQukdtO1YhOlMYHVNMU/edit#heading=h.y01yv8y4qvna

body:
- Towards #1342

Probably keep issue open until we can remove most ignores, and get down to a subset that are either stylistic choices we disagree with, or things that would be harder to fix. (and a low priority issue could be filed for followups in that case.) I don't trust my own judgement on R code: I'd suggest that we should actually try to be more stringent when linting R than with a language we use more confidently. 

Right now I've split off the linting as a separate job, but I'm not committed to that -- It is nice to have everything run in parallel, rather than only seeing the first error if they are run serially -- but if the R code is not under active development this is extra CI work and extra noise in the UI.

title: remove constant_time arg from randomized response
body: Closes #1323

title: break apart bernoulli sampler traits, add constant-time impl
body: Closes #1310

title: refactor output perturbation mechanisms
body:
Closes #1307
Closes #1308
Closes #1309

* separate constructors for each combination of scalar/vector x integer/float x gaussian/laplace. 
* removed all constructors from the public API except for `make_laplace`, `make_gaussian` and `make_geometric`
* `make_laplace` and `make_gaussian` now have an argument `k` for float noise granularity
* `make_geometric` has `bounds` instead of `k` for constant-time execution
* updated all docs/tests to remove references to the variations of `base_` constructors
* increased relaxation term for vector-valued float mechanisms

title: option FFI for R
body:
Closes #1306

This is used for the refactored noise perturbation mechanisms.

- Catch `Exception` instead of implicit `BaseException` -- The tests don't currently exercise this line, so I'm not confident about the change. Since any exception here would be surprising, would we like to log it?

body: - Fix #1276 R docs now have a favicon. Steps: - Crop `opendp-logo.png` to just the star, and saved it to `R/opendp/logo.png` - Run `build_favicon('R/opendp', TRUE)` - Remove `R/opendp/logo.png`: With it in place, we would get the big star on the readme, and that's not really needed since we have it in the banner already. - Check in the remaining files. (We don't really control the HTML that references these, so safest just to leave them all in place, even if the multiplicity of resolutions is a bit much.) The call to the 3rd party service is pretty slow, so I think checking in the files makes more than than doing it at doc build time.

milestone.title: 2024-Q2:  Doc Restructuring
milestone.description:
Restructure the documents with an emphasis on a "Getting Started" section for data scientists and developers first learning about DP. This will use examples from the more ergonomic Context API

Deeper conceptual knowledge of DP will be transitioned into other areass including a "Theory" section.

Reference: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1gyVnixpNymYpfhmqYZBEn_2CpQukdtO1YhOlMYHVNMU/edit#heading=h.y01yv8y4qvna

body:
The new notebook in 
- #1270 

is great, but we want to move to RST and doctests, so we can have R examples in parallel.

I've also rearranged the content, moving the explanation of the context vs the framework to the top, and removing the introductory section, since that is covered on the previous page.

Doing Python in RST for now, so I only need to worry about one file, but if anyone really likes the proposal in 
- #1274

that could be done here.

R examples could/should also be provided, but don't think that needs to block this.

title: manylinux2014 -> manylinux_2_24
body:
- Fix #1172

There is also a 2_28 out, but maybe be safe? I've confirmed on quay and dockerhub that these images exist. 

[Dry-run of build running now.](https://github.com/opendp/opendp/actions/runs/7935903813)

Also: It doesn't look like `build_tool.py` is referenced anywhere. I've done some linting on it recently, but before that the last commit was
```
commit ae35ac4e7457da687611117c98f279da37a9c3a2
Author: Andrew Vyrros <6577271+andrewvyrros@users.noreply.github.com>
Date:   Tue Oct 25 14:06:42 2022 -0700

    * Try manylinux2014_x86_64 (#592)

    * Switch args to toml.dump()
```

Avoiding vendor lock-in is a good goal, but I don't think we've maintained this, and it may just cause confusion now. Ok to delete?

title: Now if "stable" and "dry-run" are selected, will append "-dev"
body:
If we want to treat `r-universe-dev` like `testpypi` then this seems appropriate... but if we want to make sure that nothing gets pushed to any branch on github from a dry-run, should try something different.

- fix #1266

title: Fix masked mypy errors
body:
I'm not sure of the metric in `test_comb.py`: @Shoeboxam, can you make a suggestion there?

My sense is that `context` might go away, to be replaced by Polars, so we don't need to invest more time there? Though if it is staying, the test coverage could be improved.

- Fix #1264
- Unblock #1263

title: Remove `@versioned` from generated code
body:
- Remove one line from Rust code and regenerate Python
- Since it's now unused, remove function
- Fix #1145

(If you're looking at that issue, note that it started from a misunderstanding on my part: it's `@versioned` rather than `@proven` which is vestigial.)

title: Python and R examples in tabs on quickstart (just CI)
body: - Fix #1232 - Branching from last passing commit on #1233 Not immediately obvious to me what I did wrong pulling the CI logic into a script in #1233, and just this much is valuable, so filing a new issue here. If this much is good, there's still the question of what the next step should be: I'd be reluctant to start adding more tabs everywhere, because that's going to cause a lot of conflicts with - #1177 but that is in a holding pattern because the original plan was to wait until the polars API is ready; Maybe we should revisit that plan?

title: Fix the flake8 warnings that really need it
body:
- Fix #1260 -- Comments on separate lines!
- Fix #1069 -- Fix the ones that need fixing, and explain the rest.
- Add a couple TODOs -- Will file follow-up issues if you're in agreement.

If you would prefer to have stricter linting and fewer ignores, that could work... though if we get really strict we should probably use black and/or pre-commit-hooks.

Conversely, if you think something I've marked as a TODO wouldn't be helpful, that's welcome feedback too.

title: Error on warning from devtools::check
body:
- Elevate check warnings to errors, just to be safe.
- Does not address #1251, sadly: `devtools::document` does not support `error_on` and I haven't found an alternative.

title: Generated changes to R conf
body: I think that running `devtools::check` produced these changes; Certainly not manual. They seem reasonable, but if they aren't, I should understand what generated them so I can avoid committing generated code changes by mistake.

title: reverse ternary, so it is not confused by false-y empty string
body:
- Fix #1234

If you already have something in the works, just close this.

title: Make docs dependency on r-docs explicit
body:
make the dependency on r-docs explicit, at the cost of slowing down the docs build

- Possible fix #1242, but there are other approaches, including doing nothing.

title: R doc README
body:
Towards #1244

Just repeating the top-level README doesn't tell R users much, but I think there are a few things we could point out to them before letting them loose on the generated docs.

We are a little constrained: It should work both as a readme for this directory, and as a source for generated docs. Considered relative link to the API reference... but that wouldn't work when the README is viewed in github.

title: Tidy up R docs header
body: - Towards #1244, but keep it open We don't have total control over the header in the rdocs, and we don't have as much space (the header here is limited to content width, unlike the sphinx header) - Add logo with link - Remove changelog - Change title to "R Documentation" to reflect the scope of these pages Was: Now:

title: Subheadings in R docs
body:
- Towards #1244... but keep it open for now.

Tweaked the Rust codegen to include `@concept` in the generated docstrings. With this, R pkgdown can be configured to include headings.

If this much is useful, there are a couple of follow-ups which could be filed.
- Generate `_pkgdown.yml` in Rust, so the list stays consistent.
- Split up the `Other` catch all by adding `@concept` on the non-generated files.

title: Avoid panic in ALP histogram
body:
I think the map on this is backwards, could you check @ChristianLebeda? Thanks. This is a sign we need better proof coverage!

I also adjusted the code to not panic when scale is zero.

title: Update and fix typos on dev instructions
body:
- Fix #1223 (Actually, move every language install down to the appropriate section.)
- Correct envvar
- Add missing double backticks
- Second level headers

title: remove reference to poly
body:
- Fix #1225

Did a build from scratch with this change and there are no warnings.

title: Use isinstance where appropriate
body: - Towards #1069

title: Require explicit imports
body: - Towards #1069
